body:
You just need to update the configuration on the registry center, like the zookeeper.
@java-programmer

Thanks for your report. Can you provide more information?

Please provide the actual behavior originally, rawly and straightforwardly without any analysis. It means raw input/output data, or raw log, config...

You didn't fill in the bug report template, so I have to ask you here what's the release version? What's application(ShardingSphere-JDBC or ShardingSphere-Proxy)?

When you use setFetchSize, what's the value you set?

You mentioned you haven met problem when use setFetchSize, what is the exact problem?

At last, if you have some findings and want to analyze, please do it in a separate section.
now，common data source configuration， also support springboot  and sharding-proxy yaml

You can adjust the pool size to resolve this problem. Of course, maybe there's reason you can't change pool size, if so set max.connections.size.per.query to 1.

> +1

Hi this issue has been fixed already. If it is convenient, you can give it a test on the master branch. Thx.
For English only, other languages will not accept.
FOLLOW IT.

1. Have you closed check.table.metadata.enabled property?
2. How many databases and hosts hold that 7000 tables?
3. Please show the detail configurations of ShardingSphere.
4. Please fill in the template following.

## Bug Report

**For English only**, other languages will not accept.

Before report a bug, make sure you have:

- Searched open and closed [GitHub issues](https://github.com/apache/shardingsphere/issues).
- Read documentation: [ShardingSphere Doc](https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/en/overview).

Please pay attention on issues you submitted, because we maybe need more details. 
If no response anymore and we cannot reproduce it on current information, we will **close it**.

Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

### Which version of ShardingSphere did you use?

### Which project did you use? ShardingSphere-JDBC or ShardingSphere-Proxy?

### Expected behavior

### Actual behavior

### Reason analyze (If you can)

### Steps to reproduce the behavior, such as: SQL to execute, sharding rule configuration, when exception occur etc.

### Example codes for reproduce this issue (such as a github link).

> > +1

Besides, could you add some SQL rewritten tests in [Insert SQLs](https://github.com/apache/shardingsphere/blob/master/shardingsphere-features/shardingsphere-sharding/shardingsphere-sharding-rewrite/src/test/resources/sharding/insert.xml) to guarantee `Replace` SQL can be parsed, rewritten correctly?
> 
> @tuohai666 IMO, this PR also need your review, could you give it a careful look?

@tristaZero Thanks for your review, I will add some SQL rewritten test cases. 😀

spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.demo.table-strategy.inline.algorithm-expression=demo_$->{id % 1024}

Hi!
I believe `OrchestrationInstance` holds this data of `ip + thread-id` which needs to be changed.
I am not sure how to get the port on which the instance is running.
@swayamraina For proxy，the port can be passed to `ShardingOrchestrationFacade` when proxy starts, and for jdbc, thread id is better.

hello.
My company‘s project does not allow security risks when it is released.Therefor i can't use sharding-jdbc-core 4.1.1.
So i want to know when it can be upgrade?
Thanks.

OK. Yes, ShardingSphere will load all table names of actual datasources. The **7169 tables** in the log indicates that there are 7169 tables in ttt, although 6145 of them are not present in config file. 

I noticed that you use only one machine. If your hardware environment is not good, the meta data loading procedure will cost much time.

Can you create another database like **sss** contains only 1024 tables you really want to use and have a test?
Is this solved?

I mean database machine.

	at org.apache.shardingsphere.sharding.algorithm.sharding.inline.InlineShardingAlgorithm.init(InlineShardingAlgorithm.java:51)
`

//this is alwarys return null in jdk8 

Config as belows :

                sharding-column: user_id
                sharding-algorithm-name: checking-transaction-detail-order-inline

@xbkaishui you need config Inline sharding algorithm expression,like this:
![{0D66795B-37F0-4154-8057-32000A0667A5}_20200628152300](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33389378/85941100-5e13c700-b953-11ea-97cf-fc8c5ab7a6e2.jpg)

> @hand515 https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/cn/faq/#18-%E6%9C%8D%E5%8A%A1%E5%90%AF%E5%8A%A8%E6%97%B6%E5%A6%82%E4%BD%95%E5%8A%A0%E5%BF%ABmetadata%E5%8A%A0%E8%BD%BD%E9%80%9F%E5%BA%A6

Although setting "max.connections.size.per.query" can make it initializing faster, but it's not helpful because of some reasons:
* The database has a limit on the maximum number of client connections.
* Time is related to the number of table. More tables will take more time.
* Afraid of unknown performance problems will trigger in production environment.
That is, if there are 7169 tables, do you need to use multiple instances (machines) in the database? If so, the cost may be higher. Is there any other solution?

Hi @JOYS369   you can try the newest version `4.1.1`.

Actually, we don't expect 1222709 milliseconds for meta data loading for 7169 tables.
Time cost for one query: 1222709/7169 = 170ms
IMO, this kind of query usually cost 1~2ms or even less.

There're two possibilities:
1. There's bug in ShardingSphere. I'll double check.
2. You machine is too slow. Please provide your hardware environment. And check is there any other service running on this machine.
yes for DruidDataSource the config is right.

Or try with a back quota:
> \`source\`
okay, thank you

this pr no problem，can merged

java.sql.SQLFeatureNotSupportedException
	at com.alibaba.druid.pool.DruidPooledConnection.getSchema(DruidPooledConnection.java:1191)
	at org.apache.shardingsphere.sql.parser.binder.metadata.util.JdbcUtil.getSchema(JdbcUtil.java:41)

There are also services that use this database, but monitoring has little impact on performance.
